Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High Performance Cellular Simultaneous Recurrent Network based Pattern Recognition

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a collaborative proposal between a neural network researcher, addressing the issues of face recognition and image recognition in general, and a researcher on a new class of electronic chip based on memristors.
In recent years, new world records have been set in image recognition by convolutional neural networks, funded
at other universities through the EFRI/COPN topic at NSF. At times, those systems have outperformed humans in those tasks. On the neural network side, this team plans to use a more general class of neural networks, the Cellular Simultaneous Neural Network (CSRN), to address benchmark challenges in face recognition where computers have yet to outperform humans. The CSRN may be viewed as
a generalization of the convolutional network to add a kind of real-time recurrence or feedback, a kind of recurrence which is known to be crucial to the powers of biological brains.
On the electronic hardware side, this proposal addresses a crucial challenge in continuing Moore's Law. The speed of computing chips is not expected to grow as fast as it did in the past, but thanks to breakthroughs in lithography and the recent work in memristors, we can still expect progress towards thousand or even millions of active processors on a chip. In order to make full use of this emerging new capability, new efforts are needed to integrate device work and systems level work together, in developing new architectures of real practical use. If successful, this project could be an important step forward in that effort. Memristors for use in memory are already being well-funded by industry, but the extension to active processing and learning is more of a high risk
breakthrough activity.
This project also includes a substantial component of education and outreach, including development of systems to stimulate K-8 children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pattern recognition is considered as one of the most complex tasks performed by the human brain. This work addresses one of the long standing open challenges in machine vision: distortion invariant pattern recognition without resorting to complex training of fixed pathways of computation. Our experience suggests that emergence of a truly robust distortion invariant universal approximator will necessitate innovation in structure and learning algorithms inspired by brain scale vison processing. Such goals to replicate capabilities of human vision system are very relevant to the ‘reverse engineering the brain’ grand challenge (http://www.engineeringchallenges.org/cms/ 8996/9109.aspx) outlined by the National Academies of Engineering.

We designed biologically inspired pattern recognizer that may provide a deeper understanding on the inner workings of the human visual system and its interaction with relevant brain areas for learning. A universal approximator such as cellular simultaneous recurrent networks (CSRN) was first designed to imitate recurrency in the brain that is crucial for solving complex function approximation tasks. The capabilities of the universal approximator needed to be enhanced first to solve more complex topological image mapping tasks such as image registration. However, high level brain scale vision task such as generalized object detection and recognition require extensive innovations in both the architecture and learning algorithms for the network. Consequently, this project introduced a novel generalized pattern recognizer by utilizing the distinctive properties of a universal approximator such as extensive weight sharing, recurrency and distributed processing capability.

This NSF-funded project obtained few specific and tangible progress in the following areas: (i) Generalization and comparative analysis of universal approximators (e.g., CSRN  and multilayer perceptron (MLP)) using constrained versus unconstrained learning techniques for large scale image processing; (ii) Introduction of universal approximators as deep architecture for image registration; (iii) Introduction of novel deep hierarchical recurrent network such as in CSRN for object detection; (iv) Learning transformations and image registration with deep neural nets (DNNs) and recurrent neural nets (RNN) for generalized camera calibration; (v) Design, implementation and application of efficient deep simultaneous recurrent networks (DSRN) for complex pattern recognition tasks; (vi) Study and Quantitation of facial expression of children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) using DSRN; and (vii) Study of a novel SRN in wireless cognitive radio network for missing signal prediction.

 

In summary, this project made significant progress toward obtaining generalized pattern recognizer. This is a significant achievement considering the crucial role of robust pattern recognition in many real world applications. An efficient and robust recognizer is an essential part of any industrial automation system. Recognition is also an important task in surveillance and security applications that are beneficial for the society at large. The outcomes impacts computer vision, psychology, education and cybersecurity among others.

We presented our lab and relevant research performed in this NSF project along with others in ONR’s Naval Future Force Science & Technology (S&T) EXPO and also in local high schools. The learning models developed in this project are being tested for autism research in our lab. We trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students in research and also provided summer research experience to high school students.
